section.title: Classes of Citizens
section.para: Before we go further into the user registration process it is worth reviewing the various types of CodeX citizens. There are basically 4 of them:

listitem.para: Anonymous Users: when you first visit the CodeX site you are typically an anonymous user. To make an analogy with DocuShare you are a guest user by default. Anonymous users can browse the CodeX site but many of the CodeX services or CodeX resources cannot be used or accessed by an anonymous user (e.g. source code access is not possible, all the monitoring facilities aren't either, etc.). So we strongly advise you to become a registered user.

Registered Users: once you have created your own account (see below) you can use your login/password to authenticate yourself with CodeX. Registered users have access to all CodeX projects including source code. And since the system knows about you, it enables you to customize your view of the system through your Personal Page, monitor Forums, software release, receive support request follow-ups, site updates and many other useful things.

Project Members: users who are actively working on a CodeX hosted project. To become a project member, you must first become a registered user and then ask a project administrator to include you in the project members. Most of the time project members are part of the project team but are not limited to software developers. They can be in charge of the support activity, the project documentation or the project management. Project members can be granted different rights by the Project Administrator according to their role in the team (see for more details).

Project Administrators: registered users who create a new CodeX project are elected as the first Project Administrators. Project Administrators have full rights over their projects except project deletion - a very unusual operation - that can only be done by a CodeX Team member. In the course of the project life, the initial project administrator can grant (or revoke) the status of project administrator to any project member.

section.title: User Registration
section.para: As suggested above, the first thing to do for a newcomer is to create her own account on CodeX. Becoming a registered CodeX user doesn't imply any commitment on your part to host any of your software projects on CodeX. It simply gives you more freedom when you browse the site and allows CodeX to serve you with personalized information.
Registering on CodeX is quick and easy:

step.para: Select the "New User" item at the top of the CodeX Main Menu
Give the following information (all items marked with an asterisk are mandatory):
Password: 6 characters minimum and repeat it twice to make sure you didn't make any typo in the first occurrence
Full Real Name: what's your name again?

E-mail Address: your Xerox e-mail. E-mail that does not belong to the xerox.com domain (or Xerox affiliated domains) is not allowed. Unless you explicitly ask for permission, using an external e-mail forwarding address is strictly forbidden

Time Zone: choose the time zone you live in. Choosing the correct time zone is really important. Behind the scene CodeX stores all time stamps in GMT time. Choosing the right time zone allow s CodeX to translate all time stamps to your local time on the Web pages.

Site Updates: check this box if you want to receive site updates from the CodeX Team. This is a low traffic distribution list and we strongly advise you to check this box (default). You'll receive e-mail from us about the site maintenance, the important event in the life of the site, CodeX presentation/training announcement and the CodeX newsletter.

Additional Community Mailings: check this box if you want to receive notification about less important events. You can safely check this box as well if you want because we seldom use it. So we assure you that you won't be overwhelmed with tons of e-mail.

Shortly after you validate the registration form you will receive a message in your mailbox which includes a URL. Clicking on this URL will bring you to a CodeX form asking for your login/password again. If they match then your account is validated and you are now logged into the CodeX site.

section.para: This 2-step registration process has been put in place for security reasons. Assuming people create their account with an alien e-mail address while they have access to the Xerox Intranet, they won't be able to validate their account from the outside because the CodeX machine is behind the Xerox firewall. Therefore, an account cannot be validated from outside of the Xerox network.

tip.title: Tip: What if I loose my password or my login name?
tip.para: Don't Panic and, above all, do not create a new account! Go to the CodeX Login Page and click on the [Lost your password?] link. You'll be asked your login name and from that CodeX will send you an e-mail message with an embedded URL. Click on this URL and give your new password.

And what if I loose both my login and password? Gee! In this case use the search box and, assuming that you gave your full real name when you first registered, search for your last name and see if you can find your login again in the list of selected users. If so, apply the previous procedure. If not then contact us!

section.title: Login and Personal Page
section.para: To log into the CodeX site, go to the CodeX Site at http://codex.xerox.com and click on the "Login" item in the upper part of the CodeX Main Menu. If you typed your login and password OK, CodeX presents you with your Personal Page (). At any point in time you can return to your CodeX Personal Page by selecting the "My Personal Page" in the upper part of the CodeX Main Menu.

Your Personal Page is a crossroad from which you can quickly go to CodeX workplaces and information spaces. In the upper part of the screen you can see bugs and tasks assigned to you in the various projects you belong to. In addition the bug section also shows those bugs that you have submitted including to foreign projects. By doing so, CodeX allows you to follow the evolution of bugs that you have reported and you might be impatient to see fixed.

Another section is dedicated to the Discussion Forums and the Software packages that you are currently monitoring. To cancel any of the monitored items just click on the trash icon () next to the item label.

On the right hand side of the screen you'll see the bookmark sections. These are bookmark to your favorite pages in CodeX. Note that in many cases CodeX uses URL with enough embedded information to bookmark sophisticated items like Software Map browsing, typical search in your project Bug or Task database, etc ... Bookmarked items can be edited which means that both the title of the bookmark and its destination URL can be modified. Finally, the list of projects you belong to is listed in the lower right corner. Selecting any if these projects brings you to the corresponding Project Summary page.

section.title: Account Maintenance
section.para: You provided a certain amount of demographic information to CodeX when you first registered on the CodeX site. This and other information can be modified at any time by selecting the "Account Maintenance" item in the upper part of the Codex Main Menu.

tip.title: Tip: Use your canonical e-mail address
tip.para: The CodeX site is connected to the Xerox People Directory (MS-Exchange database), which has the advantage of showing useful information about Xerox users like their physical location, organization, phone/fax number, etc. For this feature to work you must give CodeX your e-mail address as it appears in the Xerox Directory. You can check that the Directory access is working for your account by going to your "Account Maintenance" page, select "View my developer profile" and then "More from the Xerox Directory".

section.para: Most of the items on the "Account Maintenance" page will look obvious to you. However, we would like to draw your attention on some of them:

listitem.para: Edit My Skills Profile: a user can make his resume available on CodeX. The intent here is to let people know about you, your technical background and your domain of expertise. Very useful to get to know each other.

Remember my Login/Password: by default your current login session on CodeX is terminated whenever you stop your Web browser. When you restart your browser and visit CodeX you will be asked for your login/password again. By checking this box you ask CodeX to remember about your login/password forever or at least until you explicitly select the "Logout" item in the CodeX Main Menu. For security reasons we do not recommend using this feature unless you are lazy (like me) or your desktop environment or Web browser crashes
In fact this feature was implemented at the request of CodeX users that were having exactly this kind of problem while using an operating system that is also used by over 90% of users on this planet. once, twice or (horror) ten times a day ...

SSH shared keys: this one has to do with the Shell Account service. When you are a registered user, the CodeX server gives you a personal shell account with the same login/password as for the Web interface.
